newsitem.title: FRANCE: French Justice Minister meets Dalai Lama "privately".
newsitem.headline: French Justice Minister meets Dalai Lama "privately".

text.p: French Justice Minister Jacques Toubon met exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama on Tuesday despite a warning by China against such meetings.
But France said Toubon met the Dalai Lama, who is on a two-day private visit to the French capital, as a private individual rather than as a government representative.

"Jacques Toubon visited the Dalai Lama this morning. It was a strictly private meeting to show the respect owed a great spiritual leader and Nobel Prize winner," Foreign Ministry spokesman Jacques Rummelhardt told a news briefing.
Officials stressed that Toubon is also mayor of Paris's 13th district which contains a large southeast Asian population, most of whom are Buddhist.
"France respects the sovereignty and territorial integrity of China with whom it intends to develop an extensive partnership in economic, political and cultural areas," he said.
Rummelhardt also voiced France's wish to see "a constructive dialogue established between China and the Dalai Lama".
China earlier warned French authorities against meetings with the Dalai Lama, saying they would have an impact on relations between the two countries.
The Dalai Lama earlier accused China of committing "cultural genocide" in Tibet.

"A kind of cultural genocide is taking place in Tibet" he told the French daily Le Monde. "Losing one's independence is acceptable, but losing one's culture, accepting the destruction of our spiritualism, of Tibetan Buddhism, is unthinkable."
The 1989 Nobel Peace laureate is on a European tour that last week brought a Chinese protest to the European Union over a meeting he had had with officials of the European Parliament.
Rummelhardt said the Dalai Lama was in Paris to deliver a lecture on Buddhism and for medical tests, but he did not indicate what type of tests.
The Dalai Lama is also scheduled to meet French parliamentarians, Socialist opposition leader Lionel Jospin and Paris mayor Jean Tiberi.
